newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia priest faces trial over fugitives.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia priest faces trial over fugitives.

text.p: An Indonesian Catholic priest could face trial for allegedly sheltering three activists of a banned leftist group after riots in Jakarta in July last year, one of his lawyers said on Tuesday.
"Romo (Father) Sandyawan may face trial for allegedly sheltering three activists from the People's Democratic Party (PRD), including its chief Budiman Sudjatmiko," Dwiyanto Prihartono told Reuters.
Prihartono of the Jakarta-based Legal Aid Institute said Sandyawan had been accused of sheltering people wanted by the police. The offence carries a maximum penalty of nine months.
"Sandyawan has said he was only performing his duty as a priest, that is to help frightened people," Prihartono said.
The priest's elder brother Benny Sumardi, whose house was used to shelter the activists, could also be tried on charges of harbouring fugitives, he said.
The two have not been charged, Prihartono said.
Dossiers on both men were now being processed at the prosecutor's office before being handed to the court.
Sudjatmiko and the two colleagues who were hiding with him were found guilty of subversion in April.
A total of 14 activists from the group had been sentenced to between 18 months and 13 years in jail after being convicted of subversion, with Budiman receiving the stiffest penalty.
The activists were rounded up after the July 27 riots last year, the worst violence in the capital for more than two decades.

The violence erupted after police and a government-backed faction of the minority Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) raided the party's headquarters and evicted supporters of its ousted leader Megawati Sukarnoputri.

The PRD activists were convicted on the grounds that their small left-wing group did not follow the state ideology Pancasila and they opposed a number of key government policies. The riots received only a cursory mention during their lengthy trials.
Lawyer Prihartono said the priest and his brother had not been detained because the penalty was less than five years.
After the riots, the military issued a "shoot on sight" order and the activists feared for their lives.

The military more recently also blamed the PRD as well as other unnamed "third parties" for sparking widespread rioting, mostly on the main island of Java, during the 27-day campaign prior to this year's May 29 general elections.
No arrests have been made despite the allegations.
